cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

Le réseau de cables télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie constitue le moyen de communication le plus direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique du Nord et du Sud, l'Afrique orientale, méridionale et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la Chine et le Japon. Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes doivent porter l'indication Via Eastern.

Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu' Londres au bulletin journalier publié dans ce journal. STATIONS EN EGYPTE Alexandrie, le Caire, Sues, Port-Tewak, Port-Said, Souakin. Bureau principal à Londres

div.p: KING - On October 13, at the American Mission Hospital, Assiout, of typhus, Raymond, the youngest son of George Jing, Lingfield, Surrey, aged 19.

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1904.

div.head: THE JAPANESE LION
div.p: A telegram this morning states that the Japanese loan has been an unqualified success, and that applications are pouring in from all quarters, including Paris. It is worth while considering whether this confidence in the financial capacity of Japan is altogether justified. In the first place in regard to the actual expenditure on account of the war, it appears that the total disbursements during the first six months were 270 millions of yen (27) millions of pounds sterling). This would seem to give an average of 45 million yen monthly. But a large deduction has to be made on account of initial outlays-as, for example, the purchase of the cruisers Nisshin and Kasuga-and on account of new winter clothing and necessaries for the whole army. These have been provided and are included in the total here given. Roughly speaking, the current outgoings on account of the war-military and naval outgoings included-are a little over 30 million yen per month, or, say, one million yen (one hundred thousand pounds sterling) per day. When Japan reluctantly drew the sword her statesmen asked the Diet to sanction an outlay of 575 million yen. Out of this aggregate 166 millions were to be obtained by increased taxation and by diverting moneys from special accounts, and the remaining 409 millions were to be obtained by loans. Three loans have already been floated-two domestic of 100 million yen each and one foreign of a like amount. The proceeds of the domestic loans, which were subscribed at rates giving a total of 187 million yen, are accruing gradually by fixed instalments, and the proceeds of the foreign loan are lying in London. It willbe seen, therefore, that of the Government's total estimate 128 million yen-the late foreign loan produced only 93 millionshave still to be procured. But, on the other hand, not one-half of the total has been spent hitherto, and even from the 270 millions standing in the accounts there. must be subtracted some 40 millions worth of notes circulated in Manchuria and Korea, where Japanese paper is taken readily at par. In connexion with this part of the subject it is noteworthy that not more than 15 per cent. of the expenditure leaves the country. All the rest goes into the hands of the people, and it is believed by Japanese financiers that in consideration of these large additions to its floating capital the nation would readily subscribe two or three further loans, while there cannot be the least doubt that the resources of taxation might be still greatly exploited without inconvenience. A proof of the abundance of money in the market is that, whereas the instalments of the two domestic loans due in July were only 49 million yen, 75 millions were actually paid in, the subscribers finding the investment as good as any that offered. Neither does it appear that the volume of the paper currency has swelled since the war began. The amount in circulation at the close of 1903 was 331 million yen, and the amount in circulation at the close of July was 322 millions, in which aggregate were included 22 mil. lions then circulating in Korea and Manchuria. All these facts go to show that Japan is not feeling the financial stress of the war severely, and that without serious inconvenience she could carry on the struggle for another year, or longer if necessary. It is not upon her, pos. sessing as she does the command of the sea, and thus having easy access to the arena of combat, it is not upon her that devolves the enormous task of carrying an army of half a million men overland to a distance of some 4,000 miles and keeping them supplied throughout a long campaign.

div.head: OUR NEXT-DOOR NEIGHBOR
div.p: The future of Tripoli is a matter of great interest to Egypt, and it is noteworthy that the question of the occupation of that country is once more agitating the minds of many in Italy, for since the Anglo-French Convention and the consequent agreement between France and Spain on the subject of Morocco, the balance of power in the Mediterranean has been altered to the disadvantage of Italy. In the negotiations which have been going on respecting the future of Morocco, nothing whatever has been said as to the future of Tripoli, which Italy has always claimed as her compensation for the advance of her neighbour in Tunis and in Morocco. But there is in existence an understanding between the two countries by which Italy agrees not to oppose the action of France in Morocco, while France for her part undertakes not to attempt to occupy Tripoli. The arrangement is rather one-sided, but the difference between the two countries is that while Tripoli is in reality a Turkish province, Morocco is only quite nominally a part of the Turkish Empire. But though Germany is the ally of Italy, the Kaiser is so anxious to prove himself the friend of Turkey that he will never allow King Victor Emmanuel to make a move in Tripoli. Germany now poses as the protector of Turkey in the Near East, and it is her attitude, rather than that of France, which prevents Italy from obtaining the compensation on the shores of the Mediterranean which she considers is her due.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO
NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials. 26-11-90

div.head:
THE WAR.
SITUATION ON SHA-HO
TROOPS BETTER FED
HOSPITALS OVERCROWDED
div.p: The situation on the Sha-Ho River changes very little. Many officers are reaching General Kuropatkin's headquarters, in order to replace those who have fallen.
The troops are better fed than hitherto during the campaign, but the question of supplies, not to mention fuel and forage, remains the most difficult problem.
Despite improvements in the railway, over 86,000 sick and wounded are in terribly over- crowded hospitals between Baikal and Mukden. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN FIRST ARMY.
div.p: General Linievitch has assumed the com- mand of the First Manchurian Army.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
THE SHIPS AT DAKAR
div.p: The Russian men-of-war which have arrived here are the battleships Kniaz Sucaref Alexander III., Borodino, Orel, and Osliabia, the cruisers Admiral Nakimoff, Dimitri Donskoi, and Aurora, the hospital-ship Orel, and 6 store ships and colliers. (Reuter.)

div.head:
COMMISSION OF INQUIRY
THE BRITISH REPRESENTATIVE.

div.p: The Temps learns from St. Petersburg that Vice Admiral Beaumont has been appointed the British representative on the Commission of Inquiry. (Reuter.)
The rumour relating to Vice-Admiral Beau- mont's appointment, mentioned to-day, has been confirmed. (Reuter.)

div.head:
JAPANESE LOAN
AN UNQUALIFIED SUCCESS.
div.p: The Japanese loan appears to be an unqualified success. Applications are pouring in from all quarters, including Paris. (Reuter.)

div.head:
DISTURBANCES AT WARSAW
TEN PERSONS KILLED.
div.p: Ten persons were killed, including two policemen, in disturbances which took place at Warsaw yesterday, thirty-one being injured. (Reuter.)

div.head:
RIOTS IN RIO JANEIRO
CAUSED BY VACCINATION.
div.p: Compulsory vaccination has brought about
riots, in which it is said twelve people were killed. (Havas.)

ITALIAN ELECTIONS
LOSSES OF EXTREMISTS.
The second ballots have given results, in favour of the Ministerialists. (Havas.)
The results of the Italian second ballots are even more striking than the first ones. The Extremists are suffering further serious losses in the large towns. (Reuter.)

div.head:
CARDINAL MOCENNI
FALLS DOWN DEAD AT CONSISTORY.
div.p: Cardinal Mocenni fell down dead at the
Consistory-to-day.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
TREMENDOUS AMERICAN BLIZZARD
NEW YORK CUT OFF.
div.p: A tremendous blizzard in America has cut
off New York from communication with the west and south.

div.head:
ANGLO-FRENCH AGREEMENT
RATIFICATION BY CHAMBER
div.p: The Chamber has ratified the whole of the Anglo-French Agreement. (Reuter.)

div.head:
KING CARLOS' LONDON VISIT
ARRIVAL AT CHERBOURG
div.p: The Portuguese Sovereigns have arrived on their way to London. (Havas.)

div.head: THE ELECTION
div.p: of a French Deputy of the nation will be held at Cairo on December 3.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Minet-el-Bassal and Karmous districts on the 16th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: RUDOLPH HOME.
div.p: We have received £1 from Blattner Bey for the Rudolph Home at Alexandria in memory of the late Albert Bedar- rides Bey.

div.head: TRAM ACCIDENT.
div.p: A tram ran over and severely injured a native in the left leg yesterday near Minet-el-Bassal. The man was sent to the Government Hospital.

div.head: REMOVAL.-
div.p: We are requested to state that the offices of the local weekly Arabic paper Express have been transferred to Post Office- street, near the Hotel Canal de Suez.

div.head: MORE INSPECTORS.-
div.p: At the last meeting of the Council of Ministers, it was decided to appoint three assistant inspectors to the Ministry of Interior at a salary of £20 per mensem.

div.head: ARCHEOLOGICAL CONGRESS.-
div.p: The Egyptian Government has accepted the invitation of the Hellenic Government and has decided to send a representative to the Archæological Congress, which is to be held at Athens in the spring.

div.head: P.W.D. CONTRACT.-
div.p: The contract for the annual embankment works in the province of Beni Souef has been granted by the Ministry of Public Works to Messrs. Liato & Wourlich for the Markaz of Beba and to Mr. Bramall for the Markazes of Beni Souef and Wasta.

div.head: A DISGRACEFUL HEADLINE.-
div.p: A London contemporary states that Herr von Muszynsky, a lieutenant in the German army, has written a book about the downfall of the British Empire. In the table of contents the following head- line appears :-Lord Cromer is assassinated at Cairo.

div.head: MANSOURAH. CHURCH OF SCOTLAND SERVICE.
div.p: Divine service, including a celebration of Holy Communion, was conducted on Sunday last in the American Mission Church, Mansourah, by the Rev. A. C. W. Saunders, of St. Andrew's Church, Cairo. There was a good attendance of residents.

div.head: H.M. TRANSPORT
div.p: Plassy (Capt. F. H. Seymour) arrived at Port Said on Sunday morning from Bombay, and left at midday for Southampton. She had on board 1,151 troops of all ranks, including women and children. The officer commanding was Major H. J. Farrell Palliser, Royal Field Artillery.

div.head: FIRE ENGINE FOR DAMIETTA.-
div.p: Damietta has recently received a fine fire-engine, made by Shand, Mason and Company. We understand that the engine has given general satisfaction. This is the twelfth fire-engine which Shand, Mason and Company have supplied to the Egyptian Government during the last twelve. months.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: Castellano's Italian opera company, which is at present successfully performing at the Esbekieh Theatre, Cairo, pays a return visit to Alexandria on Saturday next, when it will open at the Alhambra with Puccini's Manon Lescaut, in which the tenor Apostolou will take part. Hamlet is to be given on Sunday. Twelve performances in all will be given.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.-
div.p: As members of the choral union found a difficulty in discovering the hall where the practices are to be held every Monday at 6 p.m., it is thought advisable to mention that it is in Rudolph's Asile, behind the Sailors' and Soldiers' Institute, and the entrance door is in the narrow street between the Asile and the Armenian Church, and not through the courtyard.

div.head: MR. JOHN B. CAFFARI
div.p: wishes to inform his clients that, owing to the expiration of the lease of his old premises in the Grand Square, his offices and stores have been removed to 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane and 6, Boulevard de Ramleh. As the fittings of the offices, shop, and stores are not yet completed, some of the back stores will be used temporarily, with entrance from 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane.

div.head: PANIC IN A THEATRE.
div.p: During the performance given by the Sheikh Salama's troupes in the Arab theatre in Abd-el-Aziz boulevard, Cairo, last Saturday evening, a Greek, who was slightly inebriated, fired two shots in them hall. His pistol was charged with blank cartridges only, but the detonation caused such a panic amongst the audience that they all made for the exits. Fortunately there was no serious accident, and the author of this drunken freak was arrested.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive paid a visit to his estates at Moustoricul on Sunday afternoon.
To-day his Highness will leave Koubbeh to visit his estates on the Ismailia Canál. His Highness will return on Thursday.

Yesterday the Khedive received in audience, at Abdeen Palace, Count Stadmiky, Acting Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, who presented M. Emmanuel Gyom- roi, a specialist on Austro-Hungarian trade. The Khedive gave an "iftar" yesterday even- ing, to which H.E. Ghazi Muhktar Pasha! was invited.
The Khedive will attend the celebration of the anniversary of the death of Mohamed Aly Pasha at the Kalah Mosque on the thirteenth day of Ramadan.

div.head: SIR W. WILLCOCKS' EXPEDITION
div.p: The latest Constantinople papers to hand report that an Imperial iradé authorises Sir William Willcocks to undertake the study of ancient irrigation works in the provinces of Aleppo, Mossoul, and Baghdad.

div.head: YACHTING
div.p: The American yacht Lysistrata, belonging to Mr. James Gordon Bennett, proprietor of the New York Herald, arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Jaffa. She is flying the ensign of the New York Yacht Club. The French yacht Fiorentina II., belonging to Comte Vitali, from Alexandria to Ismailia, arrived at Port Said yesterday afternoon.

div.head: MANSOURAH'S WATER SUPPLY
div.p: Mansourah will soon have a fine and up-to- date installation for its water supply. The well-known Birmingham firm of Tangye's (Limited) are supplying all the machinery, namely, four oil engines and four pumps. Cook's Boulac works are erecting the whole of the machinery.

div.head: ASSOUAN SHOOTING CASE
div.p: The news of Mr. Sleeman's acquittal reached here by wire last night, and was received with unbounded satisfaction by his many friends in Assouan. That there would have been any other verdict but acquittal was never for an instant doubted, but the news, nevertheless, was enthusiastically received by the entire European population. The effects of such a verdict should be far-reaching, and we trust it will be taken to heart by those administering justice in the provinces. That natives should at any time, or for any reason, be permitted to molest white men without the law taking steps to prevent such an occurrence, is a circumstance which, we fancy, could only take place in Egypt, and the verdict in the present case is, therefore, more welcome for this reason. Whilst, however, in no way approving of the free use of fire-arms, we have sufficient confidence in our own race. to feel that they would not resort to such means without a justifiable cause.

div.head: BLACK AND WHITE
div.p: M. SYLVAIN'S LECTURE.

Yesterday afternoon, M. Benito Sylvain, Envoy Extraordinary of the Republic of Hayti to H. I. M. the Negus of Ethiopia, read an interesting paper before the Khedivial Geographical Society on the relations of the black and white races. M. Sylvain, who was frequently applauded, began with a description of the economic and social causes of slavery and African colonisation, and noted that the abolition of slavery had been followed by a reaction, quoting the words of the Times at the opening of the American Civil War:- "Our grandfathers committed the crime, our fathers felt the remorse, and we have to reflect on their action," and the numerous expressions since used by British and American publicists, hinting that slavery had been too soon abolish- ed. He also gave instances of German colonial methods and expressed the view that the European exploiters of Africa would find con- ciliation more successful in the end than violent methods, and that civilisation of the negro if possible by the agency of civilised Africans should precede colonisation proper.

There were two points in M. Sylvain's speech which we feel bound to criticise. He spoke of the invincible "morgue" of the Anglo-Saxons in dealing with coloured races. We admit that there is something in the charge, but should like to ask whether the French tenure of Algeria is more secure than our hold on India, and whether the great colonising races are not justified by results in keeping aloof from their subjects. A promiscuous familiarity with uncivilised races is only less dangerous than unmitigated barbarity.

Again, in speaking of the great negroes of the past century, we were astonished to hear the elder Dumas and Poushkin quoted as glories of the coloured race. Dumas was a mulatto, Poushkin a quadroon. The Abyssinian chiefs also quoted may have negro blood, but in language, civilisation, and race are as Semitic as the Khalifa and the Mahdi were. He might have quoted Tchaka and Msiligazi, the founders of the Zulu and Matabele king doms, who, if merciless savages, were also brave and able leaders and organisers, and Masupha Moshesh, the founder of the Basuto nation. Still, a paper with nothing to criticise in its contents would be lamentably flat, and we congratulate M. Sylvain on his able and courageous advocacy of the claims of his com- patriots.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman 8.9. City of Venice will mail for Liverpool direct on Thursday.

div.head: OFFICERS IN CAIRO
div.p: On Sunday, Commodore Condouriotis, com- manding the Greek squadron, with 25 officers, arrived at 3 p.m. from Alexandria accompanied by M. Gennadis, the Greek Diplomatic Agent. They were most enthusiastically received by the Greek colony and followed by enthusiastic crowds to the Grand Continental Hotel.

On Saturday evening the Commodore and his staff visited the Esbekieh Theatre, it being the benefit night of the well-known, Greek tenor, M. G. Apostolou, who, besides giving of his best as Werther, sang two Greek songs, which were received with wild applause..
At 10 a.m. yesterday, M. Gennadis presented Commodore Coundouriotis and his staff to H.H. the Khedive.
At 11 a.m. was held a solemn service at the Hamzawi Church, at which Mgr. Photios offi- ciated, after which the Greek officers called upon the Ministers.

In the afternoon they visited, first, Mr. N. Gianaclis' cigarette factory and then the Kasr el-Nil Museum. In the evening a ban- quet was given in their honour at the Grand Continental Hotel by the Greek community, all of whose leading members were present.
To-day our indefatigable guests will visit the Barrage and the Pyramids, and in the evening will attend a "Punch" given, in their honour by M. Gianaclis at the Hellenic Club.
Our Cairo Correspondent telephones:

At the banquet given at the Grand Con- tinental Hotel yesterday evening, 162 persons were present, including all the leaders of Greek society in Cairo. Patriotic speeches were made, and the band of the Inniskillings played a selection of music.

div.head: RETURN TO ALEXANDRIA
div.p: As we have already announced, Commodore Coundouriotis and the officers of his squadron return to Alexandria from the Capital on Thursday morning. In the afternoon, the Commodore and officers will be "at home" on board the flag-ship Peara to the residents of Alexandria, of whom 800 have been invited. Dancing will be engaged in in the afternoon, when the guests will be regaled with 5 o'clock tea, and the fête will be continued into the evening, a cold supper being provided for the guests.

div.head: A HUGE PICNIC
div.p: With regard to the picnic given in the Antoniades Gardens on Saturday last by the local Greek community to 800 sailors from the ships, it is interesting to note the amount of eatables consumed on the occasion by the Hellenie "Jack Tars." Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., to whose Alexandria branch the arrangements were entrusted, had to provide the following appetising fare:
1900 lbs. of lamb,
4000 beef croquettes,
8000 substantial sandwiches,
800 smoked herrings,
150 lbs. assorted pickles and olives,
1800 of fresh bread,
100 assorted green salad
200 bananas
200 dates
100 apples
150 cheese
1600 pieces of pastry and sweets
2200 liters of Pilsener beer
8000 Egyptian cigarettes
1000 boxes of matches

All the above were laid out on an immense table measuring 240 metres, which was covered with the Greek national colours. Mr. A. Beneducci, manager for Messrs. Walker and Meima rachi at Alexandria, is to be congratulated.on having acquitted himself of a huge task in a very creditable manner, for which he received the thanks of the Commodore.
We understand the same firm have been entrusted with the catering arrrangements for Thursday's "at home."

div.head: KASR-EL-NIL BRIDGE
div.p: A correspondent writes:-

This bridge is, as you have often pointed out, always dangerous for foot-passengers owing to the narrowness of the foot-way. For the last week or more the danger has increased, as the lions are being repaired and a scaffolding is erected round each, which extends into the road. One has to run for one's life sometimes to escape being knocked down by carriages and cars and motor cars, the rule of the road here being that the foot-passenger must get out of the way. Nothing is being done or thought of for the pedestrian. He is too poor to need- consideration. It is infradig. to be seen walk- ing, and that is why young native officials and others, who can ill afford it, waste their money on cabs. There is a fine drive, for instance, round Ghezireh, part of which has been made into a Rotten Row, but if you want to walk you will find no properly; made foot-path, so you take to the road at the risk of being run over.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SPINNERS
div.p: Speaking at a meeting of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce yesterday week, the president (Sir Frank Forbes Adams) said that trade was busy and every loom and spindle seemed to be engaged for many months ahead. The demand was not yet satisfied. Egyptian spinners were not so well off for various reasons, but this only emphasised the necessity for pushing on with the growth of American as well as Egyptian cotton in various parts of the British Empire where the staples could be grown,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel and Fuad Pasha left yesterday evening for Cairo by special train.
Prince Djemil Pasha Toussoun arrived at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, yesterday.
Lady Beatrice Thynne, sister of Lady Cromer, arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Schleswig with the infant son of Lord and Lady Cromer.

Vice Admiral Sir Lewis Beaumont, who, to- day's telegrams, state, has been appointed the British representative on the Baltic Commis sion of Inquiry, is not unknown in this country, having been sent out here as High: Commis sioner in 1884
Judge Tuck, of the Mixed Tribunals, Cairo, arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal:
Sir W. Willcocks will leave for the Upper Nile early in December.
Mr, Peter, A. Malone, of Messrs. Hinshel wood & Co., Alexandria, who, has been detained in Scotland on business since May, expecta.to be back in Egypt early in December.

The following is the list of passengers who left Cairo for the Nile trip by the Rameses III. to-day-Mr. J. R. Marshall, Mr. J. C, Chute, Mr. H. Wilson, Mrs. Chad Kellog, Mrs. Ar- mide V. Smith, Miss Kember, Rt. Rev. Bishop and Mrs. Morley, Mr. and Mrs. William Bas- set, Mr. E. A. and Miss M. E. Carley, Mr. Max and Mrs. Gutmann, Mr. Morehouse Ste- vens, Mrs. F. L. Stevens, Mr. A. L. Friedlan- der, Mr. L. Roth, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Vietor, Mr. and Mrs. Booth, Miss E. Booth, Col. H..M. Temple, Miss McLean, Miss I. C. McLean, Rev. and Mrs, A. W. Gross, Mrs. and Miss Pagnon, Miss Jane Pagnon, governess, nurse, Mr. L. A. Ashton, Mr. A. Saville.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mattre Albert Bedarrides Bey, the well-known advo- cate, formerly Batonnier of the Mixed Court Bar at Alexandria, which occurred yesterday evening at his residence in Ramleh-boulevard. The deceased was one of the leading figures at the Mixed Bar, and had an extensive practice. He was of French-Jewish extraction and was, the son of the first President of the Court of Cassation. at Paris. The funeral will take place this afternoon and the cortège will leave the house of the deceased, No. 5 Ramleli boulevard, at 3 o'clock.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I pass, daily over, the: Kasr-el-Nil Bridge and there I see in full view of the police, crates of birds (fowls, pigeons, and turkeys) being brought into Cairo on carts. The crates are piled two and three high, and on the top sit two or three men this in the hottest weather. The wickerwork of the orates is thus pressed down on the heads of the poor birds.. Their cries are piteous. As to donkeys, the over-loading is frightful. On the top of a full load one or even two men.
I have seen two now and then are mounted. The ankles of. the donkeys ankles is not the technical word but I don't know it almost touch the ground. I am, etc.,. A LADY READER.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: PORT SAID . H.M.S. "FURIOUS." A football match was played at Port Said on Saturday afternoon between the local team and H.M.S. Furious. A stubbornly contested game ended in a draw, each side scoring: 3 goals.
DEPARTMENTAL CORPS, ROYAL BERKSHIRES,
versus
ST. ANDREW'S.

These teams met on the parade-ground at Mustapha Pasha barracks on Saturday after- noon. The appearance of a civilian team at Mustapha is a tit-bit which never fails to bring out a good attendance, and on this occasion both teams had no lack of supporters. The visitors won the toss and elected to play. against the wind. From the kick-off, the home Team early attacked, and play was for a time confined to the visitors' territory, the defence being sorely tested. The "Saints" soon got settled down, and play was transferred to, the other end. Some nice forward play by the "Saints" gave Cowie an opening, which, he did not fail to take advantage of, and the first point was registered for Saint Andrew. The home team soon equalized, however, Fitzgerald in attempting to clear kicking the ball against the post, from which it rebounded into the net. "Saints" again got the lead from a penalty, converted by Cowie, The interval, arrived with the score-Saint Andrew 2; Departmental Corps 1.

From the restart Saint, Andrew opened out grandly, and were soon hovering in the vicinity of Wideside. The home defence cleared, however, and a break-away by the right wing looked likely to bring the equaliser, Fitzgerald cleared and a combined run by the whole front line gave Sweet the ball, and that player put the visitors two up. Play degenerated slightly now, neither team putting the same vim into their play as during the initial period. Towards the call of time the home team were unfortunate to have a fourth point registered against them, Clark putting in a shot from long range, which Wideside failed to hold. This finished the scoring and Saint Andrew retired, visitors by 4 goals to 1. The following were, the teams:- Departmental Corps: Wideside, Thane, Dyton, Duff, Kindlay, MoCormack, Isaacs, Shea, Murphy, Woolmer, and, Spencer
Saint Andrew F. C.:-Fitzgerald,, Bright, Keill, Williams, Clark, Hutchings, Sweet, Jones, Cowie, Tulloch, and Halley.

Saturday's match was Saint Andrew's first game this season, and this early success pro- mises well. We are pleased to be able to state that this club has been successful in-securing new ground on the higher level of Moharram Bey common, the new site being much better adapted to the pursuit of the game than that held last season. The club hopes to have the ground ready for play in a fortnight......

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: LE ROI S'AMUSE

C'est devant une salle aussi comble et brillante qu'aux meilleures représentations de Coquelin Ainé que M. Silvain a débuté hier au Zizinis dans Le roi s'amuse. Il a joué Triboulet avec cette puissance magique et cet art consommé qui l'ont readu si cher aux auteurs, aux poètes surtout, pour l'interprétation de leurs cavres. La poésie déjà si belle de Victor Hugo semble se transformer,s'animer sous le charme de cette déclamation et de cette mimique, la première si vibrante, la seconde si expressive. Le public alexandrin l'a bien compris et a rappelé souvent l'artiste pour l'ap- plaudir encore. Lorsque le bouffon du premier acte fait place au tragédien, l'au ditoire est aussitôt saisi et reste empoigné jusqu'à la fin. La scène d'amour paternel au deuxième sete, celle du désespoir après le viol de sa fille, celle enfin de la mort de cette enfant immolée à la place du roi, sont autant de passages admirables. Il faudrait tout citer dans ce rôle de Tri-- boulet. Quel image d'effarement épou- vanté lorsqu'il entend François Ier s'éloigner en fredonnant l'air :
Souvent femme vario
Bien fol est qui s'y fie!
et quel désespoir inenarrable dans ce cri: J'ai tué mon enfant !
Mme Silvain a été fort bien dans son rôle un peu effacé de Meguelone et Mile Barat dans celui de Blanche mérite égal.- ment tous les éloges.
Excellents aussi M. Jean Renaud dans François Ier et M. Ferrat dans Saltabadil, vrais types le premier de roi gentilhomme et le second de spadassin tranquile et froid jusque dans l'assassinat.

Cleanthis et Strabon, comédie en 1 acte de Régnard, n'a pu être jouée va l'heure tardive, 12 b. 3/4. A ce propos nous seriors heureux de voir la troupe Silvain adopter le système de M. Coquelin, à savoir de commencer la représentation exactement à 9 heures et de raccourcir autant que pos sible les entr'actes. Ce serait avantageux pour tout le monde.
Ce soir on donne Le Père Lebonnard, comédie en 4 actes de J. Aicard et Cleanthis et Strabon, comédie en 1 acte de Regnard.

div.head: Le rapport de M. Maskens
div.p: Le rapport de M. Maskens Le rapport de M. Maskens, consul général de Belgique au Caie, vient d'être publié dans la quatrième livraison du Recueil consulaire..

Nous en détachons quelques passages: Plus en Egypte que dans beaucoup d'autres pays, le bon marché de la marchandise constitue son principal élément de succès. Les produits de luxe et même ceux de bonne qualité n'y conviennent qu'à une clientèle plus restreinte qu'ailleurs. En général le goût des indigènes n'est pas très raffiné et un grand nombre d'entre eux, qui ont gaank de l'argent pendant coaders nières années d'extrême prospérité, n'ont pas encore perdu l'habitude de viser, dans leurs achate, à l'extrême modicité de la dépense plutôt qu'à l'acquisition d'objets bien confectionnés et durables.

Quant à la masse de la population rurale, dont la capacité d'acquérir était absc- lament nulle il y a quelques années et qui commence à pouvoir satisfaire à certains besoins d'un confort bien relatif encore, elle n'achète que des marchandises d'on bon marché extrême et par conséquert d'un travail plutôt grossier.
Le crédit, la représentation et les visites à la clientèle soat trois points exigeant l'attention soutenue des importateurs de produits belges en Egypte.

Le terme traditionnel des crédits en Egypte est de quatre-vingt dix jours. Comme ce terme comprend la durée du voyage, il se réduit en réalité, surtout pour les ta chandises venant de loin, comme de Bel- gique, à soixante jours et même parfois à cinquante à quarante-cinq jours.
Le crédit de quatre-vingt dix jours à partir du jour de l'expédition de la marchandise pourrait done être majoré quand le destinataire est un client habituel et de tout repos..

Bien entendu il faut agir sur ce terrain avec prudence. Mais il est certain que l'importateur disposé à faire de longs crédits a beaucoup plus de chance, en Egypte, de voir son chiffre d'affaires se développer que celui qui montre des exigences au point de vae de la rapidité du règlement d comptes, car la clientèle dans ce pays n'a guère l'habitude de payer au comptant; au contraire, le négociant égyptien doit accorder généralement de longs crédits aux acheteurs pour les attirer à lui, surtout à une époque de l'année où l'argent est rare, c'est-à-dire avant la récolte et la vente du coton. Bouvent même les contrats de vente entre indigènes se concluent avec la clause que le payement s'effectuera après la récolte du coton.

En réalité, la durée des crédits est une question d'appréciation, tant de la part de l'importateur que de celle de l'intermédiaire 01 représentant; cette durée doit être subordonnée au degré de confiance qu'offre le négociant égyptien et à l'époque de l'année où la marchandise est livrée.

Si les représentants de commerce sur les places du Caire et d'Alexandrie cffraient dos garanties de sécurité complète au pointde vue de la délicatesse des procédés ou de la connaissance parfaite des affaires, rien ne serait plus simple, de la part de l'importateur, que de s'en rapporter à leur expérience pour fixer la durée des crédits à accorder à chacun des cliente. Malheureusement, tel n'est pas le cas en Egypte pas plus qu'ailleurs du reste, et le choix. d'un bon représentant ou intermédiaire est pour l'exportateur européen une question très délicate et très difficile à résoudre car les représentants de commerce ayant fait leurs preuves ne peuvent, ou bien ne veulent pas, accepter de représentation nouvelle. Quant aux représentants débutants dans le métier, il ne leur est guère facile de fournir à l'exportateur européen des garanties indiscutables et complètes de leurs capacités, de leur activité et de leur parfaite honnêteté.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demi)
Il y a de la fermeté sur le marché mais pas d'entrain.

Nos prévisions en ce qui concerne les Eaux du Caire viennent de se réaliser. Par suite de l'abstention des vendeurs en présence de la demande, le cours a passé de 995 ce matin à 1025 acheteurs en clôture. On s'attend à des prix encore plus élevés. On constate une légère baisse de l'Agricole à 10 7/8, de la Delta Land à 3 3/4, des Markets à 26/9, de la Delta à 15 S.S. La baisse de l'Anglo-American Nile est plas sensible encore, soit de 5 11/16 à 5 716. La Bébéra hausse au contraire à 54, la Wardan à 7 3/16, les Cotton Mills à 7/6 et la Salt and Soda à 35/8.

div.head: Our Paris Letter.
div.p: Everywhere the leaves are falling-rich, golden-brown leaves of autumn. The trees keep their foliage best in sheltered spots, such as the Garden of the Tuileries, where the children play their round games, at trundling hoops and sending skywards toy balloons. For the moment, it is a nursery hung with magic apestry-this background of avenue, brilliant with the deep purple and orange of the Orient. The other day I paid a visit to Père-Lachaise. noticed about the grave of Alfred de Musset some fresh ivy, and unknown hands had deposited chrysanthemums and pansies and a bunch of the wild rose. It was a poetic homage to the sweet lyrist. The ceme- teries are the shrine of many memories these days-memories called to being by the time of falling leaves.

It would be idle to attempt to discount the satisfaction felt here at the termination of the dangerous phase of the Anglo-Russian conflict. Whatever the price paid by the British Govern- ment for this peaceful turn of events, it is all to the advantage of this country. France was frankly dismayed at the prospect of a rupture between the Cabinets of London and St. Pe tersburg, and it is easy to see why. She could not have remained an entire stranger to the conflict, however circumscribed; and it is perfectly certain that nothing is farther from the thoughts of the Government of the day than a blind policy of "follow my leader," which would plunge the country into war.

The French Government and its supporters in general, and the Minister of War in parti- cular, should be deeply grateful to M. Syveton. Had not that excitable personage committed an intolerable outrage by striking General André in the face, it is more than possible that the Government would have been beaten in Friday's division. In a speech of two hours' length the Minister of War defended the sys- tem of organized espionage and delation on the simple ground that it was necessary to the defence of the Republic against the machina- tions of the reactionaries, who had done the same thing themselves in their time. That is an extremely poor defence. Two wrongs do not make a right, even, if it can be proved that the reactionaries ever had an organized system of delation, which has not even been asserted. As three ex-Ministers said the only question is whether delation is or is not to be recognised as a regular instrument of Government. If the Republic can only be maintained by such means, it must be in a bad way; but I do not believe that any such measures are necessary, and I am sorry that so unsound an argument as "Tu quoque" should be urged indefence of a very dirty trick. Friday's debate w will certainly not raise the Combes Cabinet, or om its supporters, in the eyes of France or of the World.

M. Syveton is impenitent, indeed, exultant, up as it seems, but public opinion, except in the c strongest Nationalist quarters, condemns the outrage. There is even reason to believe that ti M. Syveton went to the Chamber with the ex-li press purpose of assaulting the Minister. This ti idea is strengthened by the fact of the curiously ez menacing language adopted by one of the lead-selling organs of Nationalism on the eve of the w debate, so that it would almost seem that the t attack was the result of a plot. It is the same species of insane and brutal argument which d prompted the assault on M. Loubet at Auteuil t races at the beginning of the President's term t of office. Then, as now, the effect of the L outrage was to consolidate the Republican senti- s ment in the country. The blow administered t to the Minister of War, whilst it threw him t from his physical balance, has set him on his political feet. After this dastardly act the whole Republican party rallied to the support of the Government. And the same spirit is to e be remarked in the Press. The Figaro, whose f editorial trumpet gives forth an uncertain sound e these days, and the Temps, which does not see eye to eye with the Government on many questions, are both emphatically condemnatory of the incident of Friday last, and of the tem- per of mind that led up to it. Nationalism of the school to which M. Syveton belongs is a political monstrosity which has grown up in C France, engendered to a certain extent, no doubt, by Jacobin intolerance and oppression. One side acts and reacts upon the other. Napoleon called into being the forces which ended by overthrowing him. The act of violence per- petrated in this case, however, is inexplicable, as M. Syveton is a man of superior intellectual attainments, being, indeed, a University professor.

Whilst General André has escaped at the expense of his own person the condemnation of an' adverse vote, such a result must not be interpreted as a condonation of the scandalous proceedings of army informers with which the pulilie journals have been ringing for the last fortnight. The system must stop, and it is certain that the country will insist on the sup- pression of the secret "fiches" which have had the effect, probably, of ruining the career of many a promising young officer.

It was not to be expected that the Anglo- French Convention would pass the Chamber of Deputies without undergoing a severe criticism. Arrangements with foreign Powers, friendly or the reverse, do not elude the vigilance of any representative national body. They are certainly not spared when they have to run the gauntlet of the House of Commons, but nobody concludes from the opposition of eloquent dissenters that they fail to meet the desires of the great majority. There is therefore no reason for alarm in the fore-and-aft raking to which M. Deschanel subjected the treaty. Frank and not discourteous criticism of this kind cons duces more to a good understanding between the nations than the concealment of hostility.

The death of Paul de Cassagnac removes a typical specimen of what Mark Twain would call "the fighting editor." Like his old opponent (with both pen and sword), Henri Rochefort, Paul de Cassagnac was a first-rate duellist, and d ever ready to prove that his sword was as sharp as his pen, which is saying a good deal, w for, like Rochefort again, his political polemics ie were of the most violent order.

M. Gaston Dru makes some striking points is in the Echo de Paris. He says:-"I have since be heard that, according to police reports, the th majority of those who insulted Count Bencken- tl dorff, the Russian Ambassador in London, S were Germans. I know for a fact that Germany offered her support and that during the last few days frequent telegrams have been ex- changed between William II. and Tsarskoe Selo. I also know that William II. is listened to, and that he directly influenced the appoint- ment of General Kuropatkin as Generalissimo." M. Dru speaks of the German Emperor's crime of "lèse humanité," from which he will derive no profit.

The heads of the Catholic Church in France are at present considering ways and means, in view of the approaching separation from the State. Several Bishops and the venerable Cardinal Langénieux, Archbishop of Reims, have gone to Rome to confer with the Pope on the new situation created. Every day schemes are presented to diocesan authorities by various indigenous persons who wish to assure the future of the Church. Certain of these plans are based upon a system of insurance; others have to do with the issue of redeemable loans, with (after the French practice) the "gros lot." Either the projects are applied to the whole country or they concern the ecclesiastical districts considered separately. There is unani- mity, however, on one point: the capital is invested abroad, from a fear, apparently, lest the Government, yielding to temptation, should lay hands on the money of the Church. All the various expedients are being discussed by a committee of Catholic jurisconsults and financiers sitting in Paris.

The celebration at the Sorbonne of the centenary of that remarkable code of laws which bears the name of the great Napoleon, but with the compilation of which he had really little or nothing to do, is an interesting tevent. Whoever drew it up it is one of the most interesting attempts in the direction of of legal reform which have ever been made, and that it has lasted, practically without change, for a hundred years, shows how successful its compilers were in evolving from the welter of the old French law, a system which is in accord with the French idea of equity. To the philosophical lawyer nothing however is more interesting about the Code than its failure. Napoleon's special object in promulgating the Code was to do away with the manifest evils. which he saw, or thought he saw, to arise in countries like England, where so large a portion of the law depends, not upon the ex- press directions of the Legislature, or even upon the natural equity of the judge, but on cases and precedents.

The official returns of the population statis-ap tics of France for 1903 have just been published, and show that at the best the popula- be tion can only be considered stationary. The g excess of births over deaths is only about C seventy thousand, which is over ten thousand A worse than last year, and not so much as one g thousand better than 1901, which was a very to bad year. Last year the number of births and ac deaths both fell off; the births by over eighteen at thousand and the deaths by over seven la thousand compared with the previous year. al There has been an increase of deaths in thirty-um six departments, against thirty in 1902 and gr thirty-three in 1901. But, on the other hand, c the births have fallen off in no fewer than M seventy-three departments, and in only fourteen have the births increased compared with G 1902. Thus it appears that in five out of every six departments the birth rate is falling off, while the death rate has decreased in half of the total number. The decrease of the population, which it was hoped 1 had been arrested, is therefore as marked as ever, and it is obvious that every year France, gets weaker and weaker compared with Germany. She can no longer find the recruits for the huge army which acts as ae counterpoise to Germany in Europe, and these returns prove that in spite of all that has been said and done, the population of the Republic continues to diminish.

The "Côte d'Azur-Rapide," the new train M from Paris to the South, holds the record for en speed over so long a distance. The average en rate, from Paris to Nice, was 52 miles an hour, allowing for stoppages. But from Laroche i to Dijon, and from Valence to Avignon, the speed at certain moments was a fraction under 72 miles. There is only the "Calais-Paris" which has a superior average, and that is over a shorter, and comparatively flat, route. The first train, which left Paris on Thursday morning at nine o'clock, arrived at Toulon at 8.32 in the evening, at Cannes at 10.20, at Nice at 10.50, and Monte Carlo, 11.30. This is a gain of an hour and a half over the previous most rapid trains. The English express, in its journey from London to Edinburgh, travels at -a superior rate of speed, but the mileage is in- ferior and the gradients probably less difficult.

According to the Patrie, the Emperor Jacques I.is now one of the inmates of a Turkish prison, having been arrested at Scutari in mistake for an absconding Austrian bank clerk. I sincerely hope this ghastly rumour is untrue. It of would be one of the saddest combinations of insult and injury that have befallen a monarchy since the days of Richard Coeur-de-Lion. How- Dever, it is added that the Emperor of the Sahara is demanding an indemnity from the 1. Turkish Government, through his solicitor, d which shows that in the course of centuriessovereigns have learnt practical wisdom; the history books make no mention of King Richard's consultation of his solicitor. It is an awful thought that the absconding bank clerk may at this moment be posing as Emperor of the Saliara.

Whilst theatrical managers in London are decreeing against the "matinée hat," Paris is settling this momentous question in its own way. The modistes have designed a hat-an ideal theatre hat-and they are endeavouring to interest the world in it. The new head-dress is a "béguin" (or child's cap), or else a tiny bonnet of embroidery or lace. It fits close to the head, so that the person in the fauteuil at the back has an uninterrupted view of the stage. The great difficulty, of course, is to launch the mode. A most active propaganda has been carried on quietly for some time, and the result is said to be highly encouraging.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: In connection with the withdrawal of the 20th Hussars from Egypt, the Army Council: have decided that a good deal of the cavalry work done there can be as well done by the military mounted police. A strong detach- ment of the M.M.P., under Captain C. Burrows, Assistant Provost Marshal at the Curragh, will embark on the S.S. Dunera at Southampton on the 18th inst., for conveyance to Alexandria, where the troopship will arrive on the 1st December. Other drafts for service in Egypt will go by the Dunera. At Alexandria the 20th Hussars will embark on the Dunera, and on arrival home on the 14th December, will be stationed at Brighton and Canterbury.
It is officially notified that the new period of enlistment-nine years with the colours and three in the reserve-does not interfere with the extensions of soldiers serving under the old terms.
Captain Sir Edward I. B. Grogan, Bart., Rifle Brigade, has been seconded for service as a staff captain at the War Office.

The contemplated reductions in the foreign service squadrons referred to in these notes some weeks ago will be first effected in the North America and West Indies Squadron. Orders have been received at Bermuda for the third-class cruiser Pallas and the sloops Alert and Fantome to pay off into the reserve there and the crews to return home. That will reduce the strength of Vice-Admiral Bosanquet's com- mand by nearly 450 officers and men.

Instructions contained in Army Orders just issued announce that the King has been pleased to approve of the Africa General Service Medal with clasps being granted to the Naval and Military forces employed in the Somaliland operations, between January 18, 1902, and May 11, 1904, both dates inclusive, provided the claims of the officers and men are approved by the Admiralty and the Army Council respectively. His Majesty has also been pleased to command that the medal be granted to those officers who accompanied Colonel A. N. Rochfort, C.B., C.M.G., with the Abyssinian forces. The medal will also be granted in silver or bronze, as the case may be, to all authorised Government followers who accompanied the troops so engaged. The clasp attached to the medal will be inscribed "Somali- land 1902-4." A clasp, inscribed "Jidballi," will also be granted to those present in that engage- ment, and to those who formed part of the guard left behind during the engagement in charge of the baggage under the command of Major W. B. Mullins, 27th Punjabis. Officers and others already in possession of the Africa General Service Medal will receive clasps only.

The Army Council have decided that a special war gratuity, upon a scale similar to that authorised for the operations in China 1900-1901, shall be issued for all troops and attested native followers who took part in the recent operations in Somaliland (including those who accompanied Colonel A. N. Rochfort, C.B., C.M.G., with the Abyssinian force), except the Somali irregular troops, whose services were rewarded from the captured stock. Every soldier and attested native follower borne on the strength of the Somali- land field force between January 18, 1902, and May 11,1904, both dates inclusive, will be entitled to the grant unless instructions to the contrary are issued in any particular case. The date fixed for the general issue of the gratuity is December 31, 1904.

The Russo-Japanese war and the present t crisis are having their effect on the Kaiser's C military policy. The scheme for the augmen- tation of the army which was brought forward last year, but which had to be postponed owing to the /weak state of the finances, has been thoroughly worked out this year. But the Emperor and his Military Cabinet have now altered their arrangements owing to the defeats of Russia in the Far East, the removal of regiments from Western Russia, and the better understanding between the two Empires, which enable Germany to trans. fer a number of men from her eastern borders to Alsace and Lorraine as a measure of pre- caution against France. The lesson of the advantages conferred by the command of the t sea in the Far East, and the absurd bogey of f danger from the entente cordiale between hEngland and France, has given the Emperor his opportunity. He has determined to push e on the construction of his new ships as e rapidly as possible, and the necessary money will be voted without the slightest difficulty. Admiral Togo and the rapid massing of the British Fleets during the past week have converted the opponents of a strong German Navy, and the money which was going to be demanded for the augmentation of the Army will now be devoted to the strengthening of the Navym an increase which is openly, and almost officially, announced as being intended for use against ourselves.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: Avis Important.
La Municipalité croit nécessaire d'a'tirer l'atten- ion du public sur ce que, ces derniers temps, les cas de rage sur les chiens out considérablement augmenté.

Dans le opurant de l'année, quatre personnes, mordues pir des chiens, sont mortes de rage, dont deux le mois dernier. Comme le Service Sanitaire n'avait pas été prévenu, les chiens a aient été laisrés en liberté.
De plus, il est à la connaissance de l'administra tion que: 17 personnes ont 6.6 mordues les deux derniers mois.

Il est indispensable que toute personne mordue par un chien, un chst, un cheval ou autre animal susceptible de rage, avise immédiatement le service vétérinaire de la Municipalité, téléphone N°1150, pour permettre au service d'attraper l'animal et de prendre les mesures requises.
Cet avis doit être donné même au cas où l'animal paraitrait en parfaite santé, oar ce n'est qu'après examen qu'on peut reconnaitre s'il est atteint de rage.
L'Administration est déterminés à employer tous les moyens pour enrayer le mal. mis ses efforts seraient impuissants sans l'assistance du public. Alexandrie, le 10 Novembre 1904.
L'Administrateur, signed W. P. CHATAWAY,

Derbams Feathers White. This ivory will be sold in suitable lots at the rate of so much go Kantar. Immature contraband ivory is gold nader pondaion that same, is not, resold, in the Beden and majs be papered ex Sedan within one month from date of purchase and a permit for ame will be issued at time of purchase.
Tea per cent. of the value must be paid by the purchasee as the conolasion of the anetion, and the balance within 6 days from abe above date.
After which period is will remain at purchaser's risk and subject to a demarrage ebarge of 100 Milis. for each Kantar per diem until whole stook is removed.
None of the articles sold can be removed before he whole of the purphase money has been paid.. (Bigued) M. Courts, Kaim., Controller.

div.head: HELOUAN RAILWAY.

table.head: HORAIRE DES TRAINS A PARTIR DU 3 NOVEMBRE 1904

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. Le train No 16 ne s'arrêtera pas les Dimanches au garage Cozzika. – Le train No 22 s'arrêtera les Dimances à Massarah au lieu du train No 18.
N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette will be pleased to receive communications dealing with matters of local interest, for publication. Notes of events occurring in the Provinces are especially welcome.
All communications should be sent to To EDITOR," and be accompanied by the Writer's Name and Address, not necessarily for insertion, but as a guarantee of good faith.
The Editor will not undertake to return any Contribution unaccompanied by a slamper and repeated sections.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
